course.subject: COMP
course.name: Software Engineering
course.description: Methods and tools for planning, designing, implementing, validating, and maintaining large software systems. Project work to build a software system as a team, using appropriate software engineering tools and techniques.
course.prerequisites: COMP 2012 OR COMP 2012H
course.exclusions: COMP 3111H, ISOM 3210

reviews.author: yhanbai
reviews.title: DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE!!!
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course is the most disappointing of course. If you want to learn something solid about software engineering or even some basic software engineering concepts, I am sorry you may find neither of these in the syllabus. The course provides you with the most methodological ideas about how to become a good software engineer, but what's hilarious is that it will not teach you the ABCs about how to even write a software. (JAVA is included in the lab, very superficial and not structured teaching)

After a whole semester of lecture, I'd say I did not learn anything I expected and need to become a good software engineer. If you are required to take this course, I highly recommend that you just SKIP ALL THE LECTURES! I am not being unrespectful, it's just a genuine advice from your previous CS fellow.

The project is the only thing you can actually learn something. You are required to construct a software(game) using java with your teammates. You could take the chance and practice your java and team work skills. Put more effort on this part and try to refine your product, I am sure you will benefit from it, which might also be the only part you can actually learn something in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kenneth is not a good lecturer in my opinion. His teaching attitude is far from satisfactory. He had prepared before-class videos for every chapter, in which you can find countless typos.

Of course, we cannot blame the teacher if the content itself is to blame. The thing I'd like to say here is to re-emphasize that the lecture is not helpful at all, and CS students should think of another way to memorize/master the lecture content.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not good at all.
mean for midterm and final is really high(since the content do not require any IQ) and you can easily get curved because of very minor mistakes in your exams.
reviews.comment_workload: I'd say the workload is fair for a 4-credit course, but considering the time you spend and the things you learn, it's not going to be a good deal.

reviews.author: Sune
reviews.title: Thinking About the World in a Certain Way
reviews.comment_content:
The UML diagram makes us think about the world in a certain way.
^ This is an actual answer from an actual quiz.

COMP3111H is the exact same as COMP3111, aside from additional requirements in the project.
I would like to warn that if you can, don't take COMP3111 here. Transfer it if you can, or simply don't take it if you're not a COMP student. While software engineering is important, this course is not what you seek.

A lot of the details of how screwed up the course is, H or non-H, can be found in 151044's review:
https://ust.space/review/COMP3111H/view/aAK2cfIms2IT7bp1ChJTnuiZgcj2q5p4


1 - Lecture
This course is supposed to teach you:
UML Modelling
Software Development Methodologies
Modelling: Domain and Use-Case Modelling
Functional and Nonfunctional Requirements Capture
Implementation (Refactoring and Debugging)
Testing (Unit, Integration, and Systems)
Design Patterns

What this course actually taught us:
Some resemblance of the above topics, and
how incompetent a teaching team can be.

Being Kenneth's course, he incorporates this blended-learning mode, where he reuses videos from previous years to give lectures, has pre-lecture quizzes, and does "in-class exercises" during the lecture periods.
I have no comment about arrangement. Whether this works is subject to personal preference.

However, I have great doubts about the arrangement of these topics.
This is a software engineering course, and there is a programming project. However, useful things for this project, such as design patterns, are taught near/after the deadline of the project. This just seems counter-intuitive.

Overall, the lecture topics are just confusing when delivered by Kenneth.


2 - Labs
The labs are... kinda useless
There were a total of 6 labs that needed to be submitted
Lab 1- GitHub Basics (very very basic)
It was useless. The TAs do not follow normal Java programming practices. You have to copy code provided. Copy, as in manually typing after they included an image of the code. Frustrating, to say the least.

Lab 2 - Java Programming
They give you a portion of the slides from Desmond's first lecture of COMP3021, and then tells you to copy badly-written Java skeleton code, then implement something trivial, and doesn't actually teach Java or familiarize you with it at all.

Lab 5 - GitHub Group Repository
Project groups are formed at this point. Groups are supposed to create a dummy repository and implement some questionable code. Then we are required to submit a screenshot of a table summarising the division of labour, and commits? I fail to see the point of this as our repository has the TAs as collaborators.

Lab 6 - IntelliJ debugger
This is the best (or rather, least horrifying and stupid,) lab the course had to offer. They included a bug in the given file, and you're supposed to fix it. They wrote code in an extremely horrifying manner, which was questionable, but other than that this actually could teach people something.

Lab 7 - Unit Testing
This was pure garbage. We're supposed to write tests with JUnit 4 (which is old) , but the given files has JUnit 3, 4 and 5 simultaneously loaded.
I have no idea how that even happened and it is, of course, completely unacceptable.

Lab 8 - Reflection
This is a LANG assignment. We're supposed to write a short reflection essay on what we learnt from the previously labs.
Also completely unacceptable. There is 0 use.

3 - Project
It was interesting. (derogatory)
Imagine a box containing everything you learnt in the lectures or (if any) labs. Now throw them all out the window.
Time to use Java (COMP3021) to write a project of a game that utilizes ALGORITHMS (COMP3711). This is not acceptable for a course with COMP2012(H) as its prerequisite.
The grading scheme of the project will be mentioned in the grading section of this review.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kenneth's teaching was subpar, and the rest of the teaching team were incompetent.
What the IA/TAs told us to do in the labs and project is opposite of what one is supposed to do/what we learnt to do.
From 151044's review (linked at the content section of the review) you can know more about everything that went wrong.

Overall, if you see Eden Wong as the IA, prepare for a world of pain.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pre-Lecture Quizzes (5%)
In-class Exercises (5%)
Labs (10%)
Project (20%)
Midterm "Quiz" (20%)
Final (40%)

I find it appalling that the % of the finals is double of the project in a Software Engineering course.

The main issue with the grading of the entire course can be summarized with 2 points
1 - Subjective
2 - Ambiguous

Another thing is, programming quality is graded by how the project performs, and not the actual programming in the project.

The unit testing part of the project also made no sense. We're first given a portion of the score after having a line coverage of 20%, but then we're ranked by our code coverage? And if 2 groups have the same coverage, they're ranked by a test-to-function ratio that limits both the numbers of tests AND the number of FUNCTIONS in your code. This makes no sense, as you're telling us not to generalize the same codes and repeat them inside other functions.
Not to mention that the whole unit testing score was supposed to be ranked, and we all know ranking in HKUST is a very good idea. (It is not)

Overall, I disagree with the marking scheme, and regret suffering for this as it seems like the scheme was designed to trick and keep students in pain.

I would like to add that Kenneth has used "give us a real view of the industry" as, perhaps, an excuse to whatever this course was, and I have no comment.

I would at least accept it if they knew what they were doing, but it was evident that they did not. Even a UGTA complained about the course management.
reviews.comment_workload:
I find the workload far more than it should be, and it's all because of the teaching team's incompetence.

Overall, the exams (midterm/finals) and pre-lecture quizzes don't bring much workload, they just make you question reality, and why this course is required in the COMP major curriculum.

The project is what made us suffer, with specification and grading scheme changes throughout the project period. In fact, before the deadline extension, the specification was updated 1 week before. 7 days.

I had to take 210 screenshots for the project report, I think I deserve to give this an E.

reviews.author: Re
reviews.title: A COMP Compulsory Course with the Dumbest Execution in the Department
reviews.comment_content:
Supposedly, this course should be an important course for students to learn concepts related to Software Engineering, either in development, planning, or communication. Which in some sense, the course curriculum has indeed covered those important concepts, but also doesn’t make them look like those are important.

The course content are the same as those mentioned in the previous reviews, but more or less will be something like:

UML modeling
Use Case Specification
Types of development
Design Patterns
Some Principles of Development
State-Machine Diagram
Unit testing

and much more that I could not care to remember as they are not that important in the exams and the projects anyways. Like literally the exam mainly testes on your english ability on reading at least 2 long essays consists of at least 600 words during the exam to get diagrams like State-Machine Diagram, Class diagram, Lists of required functionalities or use case diagram right, that you are required to extract every useful stuff regarding to the context provided in the essays AND real life implications.

And for some reason, even the course requires the student to have COMP2012/H, a series of, or an accelerated depends of Honors or not, course on OOP with C++ 11/14, the entire course bases on JAVA for god knows why reason. Although Java is a pure OOP language akin to C++ 11/14, it just doesn’t make much sense to justify the prerequisition as you will actually do the programming in Java in labs and a disastrous Project, which is restricted on Java.

Oh btw, thank god they have finally decided to use InteliJ instead of Eclipse.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Oh, nothing special, as the Prof himself and those who have written a review of this course have mentioned, the course basically taught by reusing pre-recorded videos, which lecturer claimed you can learn most of the stuff by watching the vids in 4x speed, along with preclass quizzes on the content inside the vids. Which frankly speaking, you don’t need watch them as you can just google them anyways.

During class of 2 hours long, the main thing you will do is filling in excerise worksheets, and maybe perhaps Kenneth would actually teach something from the .pdf slides. Which frankly speaking, you don’t really need attend them as long as you have a friend take this course with you.

Yeah, you can get the gist of how exactly this course works.

Oh, if you need help from the TA or lecturer, you might want to join their telegram group. Although sometimes other student of this course will be more useful than the TA and the lecturer anyways.
reviews.comment_grading:
I am too fed up with this course too a point that I dun even bother to remember it, but it more or less looks like this in this semester:

5%+5% on preclass quizzes and in class exercise
10% labs
20% midterm quiz
20% project
40% finals

The problem is the project and the labs are handled with a head TA who doesn’t even appear on the SFQ feedback by messing up everything, intended or not, during the course of the course. Almost every amendment made by him were first announced on the Telegram group first, WITHOUT properly inform the other course TAs in the course, before ever releasing an official documented amendment on Canvas. This leads to catastrophic moments where every TA would gives different response and answer towards a change made all in a sudden.

The project is on hell of example, where the head TA changed some specification of the project 48 hours before the deadline of the data modeling part of the project on Telegram, and posted the documented of the pdf on Canvas after I don’t remember how long. Which essentially made everyone had to redo at least one part of the data modeling. The grading scheme of the project even changed to a point that it discourage people practising programming decencies in exchange of points. Writing test cases for a developed software is one of the things that you will do to check the correctness of the program, but again, god knows why they decided to make the project score partially inversely proportional to a ratio between test cases and implemented methods. Intuitively speaking, the less test cases with the less methods you have implemented, you can technically achieve more scores. But this also means that you need to throw away the mindset on using private variables/methods in a class on something that is not supposed to be accessed publicly. So many things is wrong on so many level which I don’t even know whether this course is teaching proper software engineering practices and concepts.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload for everything other than the project is minimal, as long as you understand your preclass quizzes and in class quizzes, then you should be alright to midterm and final.

The labs are just easy coding to be done within 20 minutes, if they have released a proper instruction with up-to-date instructions related to the IntelliJ software, or instructions without ambiguity that was mainly caused by the Telegram messages.

The project itself takes up the 95% of the workload of this course imo, especially I have virtually 0 experience on Java. So you have to self taught yourself with almost everything in Java related to GUI stuffs, and the time you will spend on understanding the hot mess provided by your favourite head TA will be at least longer than the actual time you actually doing the coding.

Comment:
extreme case , self high only to give my marks out

reviews.comment_workload: The project is the most disastrous one. In reality, we all know the complexity of meeting client requirements. All stakeholders have their own goal of achieving the projects. Professional software engineering aims to give perfect projects TO receive MONEY. And for people like us , what matters is the grade. Yet, the grading of this project is extremely messy.  It gives a perfect simulation of a real life case. UNCLEAR client requirement, wrong expectation of the product. It really examine our performance in a real life project situation, I will give a credit to this arrangement, it allows me to learn the skills to handle the internal doubt with what to build  inside the team and the communication to client in order to ask for clarification of the details of the projects. The most weird part is, it allows us to create some features to the project while fitting the project basic requirement. But those extra features will later bring negative effects on the grading of the project. So should I add those features? Really have no idea. I dont want to just be the critic, try to give a clearer requirements next time AND add more consultation session during the lecture since mostly half of the lecture are wasted in this semester, those time can be the consultation session instead.

reviews.author: vert178
reviews.title: Learn this in class, but do the exact opposite in project and exam
reviews.comment_content:
Best thing about this course is after the project you will make some great friends. That's about it.

Content:

1. Good practices of sotware engineering that you will not use in the project
2. UML diagram equivalent to about 5 minutes of Google search
3. Use case specification and diagram
4. Requirements and testing. This part is actually quite useful, just not useful in reading the question in midterm.
5. State machine diagram. A very useful and important concept finished in 10 minutes
6. Design patterns. You will probably learn more by watching videos like https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tv-_1er1mWI
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor does not make effort to make people listen to him. The classroom is a hot mess; people are minding their own business and the noise makes it impossible to listen to the instructor despite sitting at the first row. I guess that's why there are online lecture videos on Canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
I hate the project and I hate the marking scheme. The marking scheme is designed in a way that encourages us to do EXACTLY THE OPPOSITE of what is deemed "good practices of software engineering" in class, e.g. refactoring code, using design patterns, writing comprehensive unit tests. Instead, the project marking scheme requires us to minimize our test cases, make every member variable public instead of using get/setters, and discourages code maintainability for the sake of test coverage.  In one of the functions, we are graded based on how few test cases other groups implement (and the penalty is quite heavy too - if you rank the 70% percentile, you final marks will get discounted by 70%). This not only promotes unhealthy competition (I tried asking other groups how to optimize test cases and got a cold reply), but also makes the outcome of our grades very unpredictable. The TA also frequently changes project requirements and only announces important updates on telegram, instead of via email or via canvas.

Students are not provided with clear guidelines with how to draw diagrams such as the UML (the instructor essentially brushes it off with saying they will try to be lenient in the grading) but marking turned out rather strict and somewhat arbitrary, and missing a single association in the midterm costs 4% of the total paper.

This is on top of the fact that COMP3111 is a COMPULSORY course, and I think all of these combined makes COMP3111H a terrible experience overall.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you do not count the amount of java black magic we have to do to get around the marking scheme of the project, then this course has a very light workload. You have to pay consistent effort attending the lectures to get the answers for the quizzes but that's about it.

Oh yea there is an essay in COMP3111. They decided the best lab task for the lab session about documentation is to write a one-page essay about what have I learned in this course.

reviews.author: sleepingbag
reviews.title: Not bad course
reviews.comment_content:
There are introductions about how to translate requirements from application domain to technical domain, how to translate technical domain to implementation details, how to plan the project and what to beware of when doing the planning, what action to take to avoid cost for developing the project, etc. You'll also get experience with a group project that involves designing UI, implement functions, using github, write requirement description to discuss with the customer (TA), draw GANTT chart, do testing.... Basically many taught content could be seen in the required element in the project.

The course tries to cover the entire lifecycle of software development. It is really hard to cover all of them while giving students some good practice on each topic. I agree that simply study those theories but not actually practicing could lose a lot of effect on learning, but this is hkust's plan for CS student and all what professor Kenneth is to try to give us everything in a course. I believe Kenneth and the TA spend a lot of time designing the project to let student get as much hands-on experience as possible.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It's blended learning mode: watch video before class and do the lecture exercise during the class.

To be honest the slides are hard to study, more specifically the slides are not designed for students to study for the exams. However the slides do provide sufficient information about software engineering.
reviews.comment_grading:
I give an A here to address how large the A+ range is. After revealing the score for the final, I think my letter grade could be between A- to A, but eventually turn out to be A+. If you want to know how the A,B range is distributed, you might need to refer to other posts.

My suggestion on getting a good grade is:
1. For midterm study quiz questions and beware of important parts in the slide, try to memorize them if possible. Midterm is easy and shouldn't get a low score
2. For project, try to get almost full mark. Many teams get full mark so I believe if you scheduled it well it shouldn't be hard to get almost full. Apart from following the provided instructions, it is important to build the project in a way that makes sense to you in each part. Eventually there would be a project demo where you need to explain why you design to do something.
3. Final: It's the most important part, there are really long descriptions for the problems for drawing diagrams. To study it's better to get used to capturing necessary information for each diagram in a long description. I think it's indeed a little bit based on luck but that shouldn't influence too much if you study well.
reviews.comment_workload:
Lecture exercise + Quiz: Really light workload
Midterm + Final: Same as other courses
Lab exercise:  takes around 1 hour for each exercise, 7 in total

Project = Activity 1 ( hand in a document ) + Programming + Activity 2 (another document) + A chill demo

Activity 1: It would take around 3-4 hours because it's the first time for student to draw the class diagram, write user requirement specifications, etc. But it's not really difficult.

Programming: I think most of time taken is for the discussion with  the teammates. The assignment itself is not hard at all. But you have to wait for your teammate or discuss how to combine the work from two people, etc.

Activity 2: If you do the programming well, activity 2 is easy.

reviews.comment_grading:

Project 20%

Eclipse is used for labs and project but IntelliJ is also approved. However, the instructions for labs and project are very confusing and inconsistent. Your marks get deducted for something you didn't do and they didn't mention but they expected you to have done so. reviews.comment_workload:
In a semester, you will have
20 pre-lecture quizzes, 20 in-class exercises, 8 Labs, 1 Team Project

Every week, 2 quizzes before the class. Each contain 5 MC problems taking less than 5 mins.

Attendance somewhat mandatory because you need to do 2 in-class exercises every class. But you are going to do it with professor, and you will get full mark even if your answer is wrong.

Lab works would take less than 30 mins. You can also complete them even without attending the lab as you can just follow the lab instructions.

Team Project does will not bother you much because most of the time you will work alone. You will select your own part to work on.

Seems there's a lot, but I felt workload is comparatively lighter as most of them are easier than any other COMP assignments.

reviews.author: asdfghjkl123
reviews.title: Better grading than expected
reviews.comment_content:
Lectures' topics include:
1. Introduction
2. Modeling Software Systems using UML
3. Software Development
4. Domain Modeling and Use Case Modeling
5. Use Case Specification and Non-Functional Requirements
6. Implementation
7. Unit Testing, Integration Testing, and System Testing
8. System Analysis and Design
9. Design Patterns
10. SQA
11. Managing Software Development

This course only teaches about the most fundamental and basic things about software engineering. To be honest, I don't actually learn much new things from the lectures. The powerpoint slides are hard to read and too colourful. Personally, I don't prefer this kind of slides, but I understand that it is difficult to have clear and  organised notes for software engineering.
reviews.comment_teaching:
We have to watch pre-lecture recording videos on Canvas before attending every weekly lectures. During the lecture time, we have to do in-class practice exercises.

Kenneth only reads nearly every words on the powerpoint slides. He seldom gives extra explanations on some points. I have to Google myself if I want to know more or I have doubts on some certain points.  He is not teaching badly but definitely not the best.

Kenneth is nice and really wants to give us good grading. During lectures (not pre-lecture recordings), he sometimes says that this kind of question will/won't be appeared in the final exam. Before final exam, he provides us a set of MCQs, which some questions will appear in the final exam. Also, he talks about the question type of every final exam question, like Q4 is about drawing UML, Q7 is about unit testing. During final exam, he even gives us hints.

For the TAs, I am a bit disappointed. Firstly, it is good that we have a telegram group and thanks for that. However, TAs usually replies students' questions after a long period of time, like a few hours later or a day later. For the labs, which is prepared by TAs, sometimes there are unclear instructions. Especially for Lab 7, it is a nightmare. Many students have troubles when trying to get the expected results. When asking the TA in charge, the TA only says the lab exercise should work... When students ask questions about this lab, the TA sometimes relies something irreverent. Finally, a student, instead of that TA, solve the problem of this given lab.
reviews.comment_grading:
Course Requirements:
Pre-Lecture Quizzes 10%
In-class Exercises 10%
Labs 10%
Project 30%
   Activity 1 5%
   Activity 2 25%
Final Exam 40%

My grade:
Pre-Lecture Quizzes 10/10
In-class Exercises 10/10
Labs 10/10
Project (mean: 92.09/100)
   Activity 1 30/30
   Activity 2 70/70
Final Exam 77.9/100 (mean before score appeal: 75.33 (combine with COMP3111H))
Overall 91.16% --> A
reviews.comment_workload:
Less workload than a normal 3 credit courses

Pre-lecture Quizzes:
Easy with all MCQs. Given two chances, after answering for the first times, the correct choices of MCQs are displayed. So, just simply screenshot it and try for the second time.

In-class Exercises:
No matter do the exercises wrongly or correctly, marks will be given. That is if you attend lectures, you should be able to gain the marks for in-class exercise.

Labs:
Theoretically, all labs can be finished very fast. Not all labs have to be handed-in.

Project:
The project doesn't really help me to understand more about the content of this course. It is a team project (Java) but can finish it in 2-3 days. The most difficult part may be the use of Eclipse (really baddddd).

Final exam:
Open-book. Hints are given before and during the final exam. I am speechless with the marking scheme, even for the TAs, they can't explain about the solutions...

reviews.author: {Curly Braces}
reviews.title: WTF is this...?
reviews.comment_content:
Simply asking, WTF is this?
The course basically talks about what software engineering activities will do from the beginning.

Syllabus
1.Introduction (L1)
2.Modeling Software Systems using UML (L2, 3)
3.Software Development (L4, 5)
4.System Requirements Capture (L6 - 9)
5.Implementation (L10, 11)
6.Testing (L12 - 14)
7.System Analysis and Design (L15 - 18)
8.Software Quality Assurance (L19)
9.Managing Software Development (L20)

The order is messed up I would say. Why are you doing system analysis after testing? This, unless you told me you are not teaching these stages in order, or else it really makes no sense to me.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Indeed, Kenneth is generous and tried his best to make us to have a good grade and reasonable amount of A-range as possible. He also tried his best to make the lecture videos with quality in the summer so that we can have a more relax-paced blended learning mode course.

Then, onto slides. It is colourful. Just WAY too colourful. Sometimes some unimportant words are highlighted, which can confuse us when making notes. Also, as it is pdf version, the words that are supposed to appear after animation will not be there in the pdf.

The TAs. Well, their tips on project are so useful (sarcasm intended). "The truth lies in the dataset, make sure you provide the most COMPLETE and ACCURATE data", that's basically what exactly what our TA reiterates every time we asked questions about the project. I think this sentence will forever echo inside my brain.
reviews.comment_grading:
Welp, Kenneth is generous with grades. But just *WAY* too generous.
This makes the mean *WAY* too high. Especially for exam, Kenneth even give tips on exam. This surely made some stress on  us not to make careless mistakes. But who cares? It's all about guessing and luck because you can't read Kenneth and the TAs' minds.

Grading scheme:
Class Quiz: 10%
Labs: 10%
Class Exercise: 10%
Project: 30%
Final: 40%

My scores are as follows:
Class quiz, Labs, Class exercises: 100%
Project: 98.5/100 (Mean: ~91.1, SD: ~12.3)
Final: 79.7/100 (Mean: ~76, SD: ~6.1)
Final grade: A (91.4%)

My group lost 1.5 marks in project because we generalized the use case diagram in Activity 1. WTF? That's what you told us to do in lecture, why do you punish us for doing that?

Welp, as you can see the grade is generally good, or is it? Here is my teammates' statistics:
Teammate 1: ~90.5% in total => A-
Teammate 2: ~89.4% in total => B+
Yes, I am not joking here. 1% = 1 subgrade??? I don't know if it is just a special case or something, but it happened. I believe it is because too many people got nearly full mark in everything (except exam, of course), and had a small SD in final, resulting in such a tight grade range.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload I would say it is slightly tight.

For quizzes, it is given 2 attempts and the correct answer will be shown. So in fact, student can basically randomly answer the question in the first attempt, and memorize the answer, and answer the correct answer on 2nd try. In fact, we don't even need to watch the lecture video to do the questions.

For class exercises, Holy cow. The time provided is very tight. Especially for students who do their work on paper (i.e. me). Let's say you were provided 20 minutes to do the exercise, you need to leave about 5 minutes to scan and upload your work. So you actually have 15 minutes to do.
Luckily, you don't have to get the exactly correct answer to get the score. They give you score if you are doing something similar. If so, one can simply randomly draw some diagrams that's looks like what the question wants and get the score.

For labs, they teach you something that are rather simple, like how to make GitHub repo, how to do commit, how to use Eclipse (Though I used IntelliJ in the end lmao), how to code some basic Java, how to make unit test blah blah… Those things are actually easy if you have some basic knowledge on those, like done a project (e.g. COMP2012H), or went for internship before.

For project, seriously, I say it is quite cursed. As I said in grading section, my group lost 1.5 marks as a punishment of generalizing the use-case diagram, while the lecture telling us to generalize cases that are too specific. Their borderline on this really shifts back and forth.
For the second activity, I must say the scale is small. The workload is about like 3 PAs from Java Programming course combined. Therefore, we can basically done the main core in 2-3 days. We even upload Gantt chart and Burndown chart that is made in like 2 hours by checking against our GitHub commit log, and still get full marks on documentation.
Sarcastically, that "truth" within the dataset, according to our TA said, actually means everything. We did not filter out any inaccurate data (e.g. sudden drop in number in "accumulative" data) and still get full mark in source code part. I searched up on the origin of the provided dataset, there already exist some errors like the aforementioned one. Indeed, complete and accurate data is what the client, i.e. the TAs want, but I must say this tip really put me in worry for sometimes.

Exam, even though it is open notes, I am totally speechless. Kenneth even give us tips on exam, trivialized some questions on the exam. But still, ambiguity exist in the exam.
Firstly, the UML diagram ones, their model answer added multiplicity next to aggregation, while the lecture told us that aggregation already implicitly gave multiplicity so it is not necessary to write it down.
The State Machine Diagram question even give a quite misleading instruction, causing most of the students got it wrong (According to TA in-charge) and lose 1.8 marks (Indeed it seems small, but remember it is about 0.3 SD in this exam. It contributes to 0.72% of total grade score and, in this case, may cost you a sub-grade!).
These places surely makes the exam itself more than just cursed.

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: Nightmare, the next comp course to revamp.
reviews.comment_content:
If I have to conclude this course: For those who have Software Engineering experience before may/may not learn something from this course; For those who have no idea what software engineering is, you will still know nothing after this course.

Software Engineering is a very interesting topic, unlike Civil Engineering, they may visualise the structure, calculate the forces, stress/strain, and usually they know can the building withstand different shocks in design stage. However, Software Engineering is a completely different topic, there is no single "best structure" to tackle certain problems and usually we cannot foreseen how does the final system behave, or ensure it is bug-free. It is an artwork.

However, this course probably was designed in the worst way of teaching Software Engineering, cover everything but not deep enough, not even at a point to understand why I have to do these things.
------
The Lecture Contents are mainly:
1. Modelling Software System
This is an important topic, may be it sounds a little bit stupid to draw those class diagram, but it is a way that developers communicate, when you work in the industry with larger system/complicated structure, drawing class diagram is important for communication.

2. Software Development
Introduction to some software development pattern but too brief, basically if you have not participated in that pattern before, you will not know why it is good/bad.

3. System Requirement Capture
4. Implementation

5. Testing
Testing is taught in a dumb way that basically it covers those basic ICT stuff and teach you to draw more diagram. They also teach Integration Testing Using Stub which is very important if you are in Test-Driven-Development, but they omit the important part that is the implementation of Stub (Loosely-coupled principle).

6. System Analysis and Design
Design Pattern should be the most valuable thing you can learn from this course, some principle like "loosely-coupled", "composition rather inheritance"... are taught, but only a very brief introduction. BTW his slides is using all the images and derivation of a book: "Head First Software Development" which is a starter-friendly one. Check out this book to learn something valuable.

7. Some QA and Management Stuff
------
Kenneth's slides are colourful, hard-to-read and vague. You may always find some statement like: "Ignore the inappropriate requirements". Thanks for that information.

I have no big problem with Kenneth's slides since it is quite hard to cover all important material within 1 semester, it's fine. However, the arrangement of project is really a mess, I will talk about that in Teaching part.

If you do not have any Software Engineering experiences, when you read the slides and attend the lecture, you may think: why am I wasting time for this????
Indeed, studying this course without any prior knowledge just like reading a random book written by a random guy, and follow his rules to complete some tasks without any rationale/understanding. But believe me (not Kenneth kind of "believe me"), Software Engineering is a very important topic and it is way more fun than what you experienced in this course.

For those who want to take this course (CPEG/ IT minor) and really want to learn solid Software Engineering, don't register this course, go find an internship instead, it is a waste of time and effort.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Let's start with Kenneth. Kenneth is nice and he always try to please students, that makes this course a bit exam-oriented since he always say "this will be in the final exam", but still I think he really want students behave well and get good grades (he even provide hints during the final exam).

For the TAs, let's start with the labs.
We have 8 labs this year and each lab is teaching something that will be used in the team project. Something like Git and GitHub, JUnit, JavaDoc...etc, but don't expect to learn Git inside this course, they merely teach you the command to stage/commit/branch/push/clone, without much rationale behind it.
I am pretty sure some TAs are not well-prepared because there is some bug during lab7, the TA claim that it works on last year, and finally a student help the TA solve the problem. And the problem is "deprecated module", sarcastically happening in a "Software Engineering" course.

When we have questions about the lab, usually the TAs they are not quite sure about how to deal with it. I guess it may be the problem that they are selecting Eclipse as an IDE, and I wonder who is the genius that come up with the idea using Eclipse for this course. Google: "why Eclipse IDE is bad", you will know how painful it is doing all the stuff using Eclipse.

The next one is Project, I am speechless with this project.
The first problem is that the project scale is too small, I am not talking about the number of team members in each team but the tasks we are doing can basically done within 2-3 days, which does not really have to be a Team Project.

The next problem is interesting, this course is Software Engineering. So I expect we are doing something like modular development (every teammate do one feature and merge together). However, it is not what the TA expect. When someone asking whether they can use separate controller classes for different tasks, the TA said he suppose us to do all our development inside one class. WTF???? Don't they know there is something call MERGE CONFLICTS???? No single company will code like this.

Finally, in the grading of the project, this course is Software Engineering. So I expect they are checking whether we are doing some Software Engineering Best Practices (comments, organised, easy-to-read code, refactor code...). But NO, they don't look at the source code, as long as your application is working and you submit all the requirement documents, you are good to get full points. WTF??

Every Team has a TA as Team coach, but actually the team coach is not necessary except you can ask about his/her grading criteria, that's it.

So what is the point of doing this project???
reviews.comment_grading:
---Update after grade release---
To be honest, this should be the most "good grade" course in CSE department, of course here my definition is the overall grading instead of whether the grade reflects ability/hard work, scoring mean in this course yields B/B+, me personally get mean in exam, project slightly above mean but I miss 1% in quizzes. Total score of 88.xx% that leads to a B+ grade which is unexpected.

However, it is still worth mentioning the exam format.
This year Kenneth tries to avoid ambiguity, so instead of drawing the whole class diagram, he gave a skeleton diagram and we fill in the multiplicity into it. There are several reading comprehension, weird questions and ambiguous questions.

When I am doing the exam paper, I feel so disappointed, feeling like an idiot fooled by others to take an exam of searching stuff from notes (the exam is open-notes), reading passages to fill in the blanks, and draw a state-diagram to some "SOFTWARE SYSTEM" which is just a vending machine. I want to give up the exam several time as it really does not examining anything. If you ask experienced FAANG Software Engineer to take this exam, believe me, they will also get the mean mark.

They release scores for individual problems, and this is the first time that I get every single questions so close to mean. Not only me but also my friends, everyone is getting similar scores on each problem. The reason behind this is that TAs are just following Kenneth's marking scheme, and his marking scheme is crazily picky and not reasonable. In the appeal section, one TA also thinks that our consideration is correct, but Kenneth just don't think it is necessary, the TA has to follow the marking scheme and give out points.

The course is a good grade course in the sense that, every person gets the same score, the s.d. of final exam is around 6 out of 100, which is super crazy for a COMP course. Kenneth does keep his promise to maximize A/B ranges, and put as much B+/A+ as possibles. That makes 88% gets B+ but 92% gets A+.

For those A-rangers, it is a hard course to get A, but if you are just an average person and don't mind learning nothing, register this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course has basically no workload, or if you compare it with other courses, it worth at most 3 credits.

Out of those 3 credits, 2 credits come from Eclipse.
It take you some time to boot up the whole IDE, and when you add some files into the workspace folders, you are very likely not to see them in the IDE. Then you have to shut down Eclipse and open it again. No Auto-Complete means that you have to type every fxxking character. When you edit some code you try to see its effect, it takes Eclipse some time to figure out the build gradle file, and run the gradle project. And there is a very high chance to fail since you did not set up the build path correctly. What is buildpath?? Sorry, it is not taught in labs. Find the solution yourself.

When you face some problem in Eclipse and try to StackOverflow, usually there is no question asked for your problem cause any sensible programmer would not use Eclipse IDE anymore. If you can find something, there is a high chance that the answer is: it is the intrinsic design problem of Eclipse, remove all folders from workspace and restart Eclipse.

There can be so many cool things that this course can do, e.g. Remove all the lectures and focus on one big project. The team coach guide you to finish each tasks and teach you some Software Development Practices, also your team can choose a development pattern you like. Having meeting with Teach Coach every week to report progress and ask for suggestions. Finally, assessment based on the practices used, the way the team tackle problems...

Of course there are still a lot of ways that this course can be conducted, just not the current way.

reviews.author: HokJa
reviews.title: HIGHLY controversial but REALLY GOOD grades
reviews.comment_content:

Many conceptual stuff, I think it's not very up-to-date, but still quite applicable in today's workplace.

reviews.comment_teaching:

reviews.comment_grading:
Well it's a highly controversial part in the course. Imagine there are >10 students are angry and talked about it in the OFFICIAL telegram group lol

But cannot deny that Kenneth is really lenient in grading so I gave an A. I think so far it's the easiest & best grading course in COMP3XXX.

Lab: full mark
Project: 30/30+59/60

reviews.author: Hei123
reviews.title: God does not play dice, but Kenneth does.
reviews.comment_content:
Modeling Software Systems using UML
Software Development
System Requirements Capture
Implementation
Testing
System Analysis & Design
Software Quality Assurance
Managing Software Development

Simple but boring and I don't think the materials are useful and up-to-date. The only thing I found slightly useful is System Design, but it was taught quickly and poorly.

There is a project in the course, but it was poorly designed and you will never apply what you've learnt from the course. All you learn is how to use github. I think it could be better if it was designed in a way that we could use some system design in it. Implementation is the best way to learn.

Overall speaking, google and learn will be better than studying this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I like the way of pre-recorded lectures and quizzes, but the questions in the quizzes are stupid sometimes and you have to guess the wordings.

Having pre-recorded lectures is a good idea, but Kenneth is just reading everything aloud. Most videos last 20-30 minutes, but you will frequently see NG clips (cost about 5 mins) recorded by Kenneth in each video, and he doesn't even bother to cut them out. From his face, I feel like he's about to say the F word but he can't lol.

For the TAs, I would give an E. Their names are Maryam, Dimitris, Kexin, and Namkiu. From their project, zoom proctor, and final grading, I would say their attitudes and working manners are poor (except Dimitris). They always release our scores before each question has been graded. Also, they never tell you what you've done wrong. They won't even give you a comment and sometimes your score is even missing. When you send an email to ask for a comment, they just ask to appeal. Seriously??? After appealing, they told me that I got 0/10 for commendable features. lol wtf. I'm tired of sending a second appeal. Btw, Maryam graded my project. I asked a friend of mine and he was graded by Dimitris. He included fewer extra features than mine, but he got a higher score for commendable features.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pre-Lecture Quizzes 10%
In-class practice Exercises 10%
Labs 10%
Project 30%
- Activity 1: System Requirements Specification (5/30%)
- Activity 2: System Implementation & Testing (25/30%)
Final Exam 40%

I'm not sure about the grades, but no matter how Kenneth claims he is lenient in grades, it is useless. The TAs never mark the works appropriately. Just rmb to appeal, appeal and appeal. The mean of the final changed from 40 to 50 lol.

The final exam is disastrous, like in lectures they tell you that UML diagrams do not have specific answers, but in exams, you will be graded with a model answer, that gives all or nothing. The question asks you to identify mistakes in the class diagram, but if you have studied the course, you will know class diagrams are kinda subjective and there is no exact right or wrong. So all you need is to guess the mistake.

Btw, if you study this course, be aware with your English as it might sometimes cost you a score. e.g. In Lab2, if you wrongly say "implements" using the word inheritance but not interface, your score will be deducted.

[Edit 1] Poor score but Good grades.
